text: Who laid the foundations of the earth, that it should not be removed for ever .
text_kjv: Who laid the foundations of the earth, that it should not be removed for ever .
text_niv: He set the earth on its foundations;it can never be moved.
text_esv: He set the earth on its foundations, so that it should never be moved.
text_nlt: You placed the world on its foundationso it would never be moved.
text_msg: You set earth on a firm foundationso that nothing can shake it, ever.
text_nasb: He established the earth upon its foundations, So that it will not totter forever and ever.
context: Psalm 104 is a hymn of praise to God as Creator and sustainer of the universe. To understand verse 5, we must appreciate the ancient Near Eastern (ANE) worldview. Ancient people, including the Israelites, did not possess our modern scientific understanding of the Earth's structure and movement. They often envisioned the Earth as a flat, stationary disk supported by pillars or foundations. The heavens were a solid dome (the firmament) holding back the waters above. This 'waters above' concept is crucial. The verse is not intended as a scientific declaration but as a poetic expression of God's power and stability. The phrase 'that it should not be removed forever' speaks to the perceived stability of the Earth in contrast to the chaotic forces of nature. The threat of floods, earthquakes, and storms were ever-present realities. The psalm uses the imagery of a firmly established Earth to emphasize God's unwavering control and faithfulness. It's important to note that the language reflects the observable world as understood by the Psalmist, focusing on the experience and relationship with God rather than scientific accuracy. References to 'foundations' resonate with the ANE practice of building temples and important structures on strong, deeply embedded foundations to ensure permanence and stability. God's laying of the Earth's foundations emphasizes His supreme architectural skill and divine power. Understanding this ANE context helps us avoid misinterpreting the verse as a scientific statement and appreciate its theological significance within its historical setting.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 104:5 underscores God's role as the sovereign Creator and sustainer of all things. The act of 'laying the foundations' signifies a deliberate and purposeful act of creation, highlighting God's intelligent design and meticulous planning. The phrase 'that it should not be removed forever' speaks to the permanence and stability of God's creation. This is not necessarily a statement about the literal, physical Earth's unchanging nature (considering geological changes and, from a Christian perspective, eschatological events). Instead, it emphasizes God's faithfulness and the enduring nature of His covenant with creation. The stability of the Earth, as perceived by the Psalmist, serves as a metaphor for God's unchanging character and unwavering commitment to His promises. The verse connects to broader biblical themes of creation, covenant, and God's providence. It affirms that the universe is not governed by chance or chaos but by a loving and powerful God who established it according to His perfect plan. The immovability of the earth, in this context, points to God's reliable presence and constant support, offering comfort and assurance to believers. It reinforces the idea that God is the ultimate foundation of our lives and the source of our security. Moreover, it implies a moral order established by God, a framework within which humanity is called to live responsibly and in harmony with creation. The image of God laying foundations reminds us that true security and lasting stability are found not in earthly things but in God Himself.
application: Psalm 104:5 offers several profound applications for modern believers. First, it encourages us to appreciate and respect the created world. Recognizing God as the foundation of the Earth compels us to be good stewards of His creation, caring for the environment and using its resources responsibly. This challenges us to confront issues like climate change, pollution, and deforestation with a sense of moral obligation, acknowledging that our actions have consequences for the stability of the planet and future generations. Secondly, this verse speaks to our need for stability and security in a world often characterized by uncertainty and change. In times of personal crisis, societal upheaval, or global instability, we can find comfort in the assurance that God is the unchanging foundation of our lives. Just as the Psalmist saw the Earth's stability as a testament to God's power, we can trust that God's promises are steadfast and His love endures. Thirdly, the verse challenges us to build our lives on a solid foundation. Just as God laid the foundations of the Earth, we must lay the foundations of our lives on His truth and righteousness. This means grounding our values, beliefs, and actions in God's Word and seeking His guidance in all that we do. This verse further serves as a call to resist the temptation to seek security in fleeting things like wealth, status, or power. True and lasting stability comes from a relationship with God. It reminds us to examine the foundations of our lives and to ensure that they are built on the solid rock of Christ. Moreover, it calls us to be sources of stability for others, offering support, encouragement, and hope in a world that desperately needs it. In a world of constant change and shifting values, Psalm 104:5 reminds us of the eternal, unwavering foundation of God's love and power.
prayer: Heavenly Father, Creator of the universe and foundation of all that exists, we thank you for the stability and beauty of your creation. Forgive us for the times we have taken your gifts for granted and for our failure to be responsible stewards of the Earth. Lord, in a world filled with uncertainty and change, remind us that you are our unchanging foundation. Help us to build our lives on your truth and to find our security in your love. Grant us the wisdom to discern your will and the strength to follow your path. May we be sources of stability and hope to those around us, reflecting your unwavering love in all that we do. We praise you for your faithfulness, your power, and your enduring presence in our lives. Amen.

It uses poetic language to express God's power and the perceived stability of creation within the context of the ancient Near Eastern worldview. The focus is on God's faithfulness, not scientific accuracy.
